\phantomsection\label{index::doc}



\chapter{Introduction}
\label{intro:introduction}\label{intro:plant-costsse}\label{intro::doc}
The set of models contained in this Plant\_CostsSE are used to assess the balance of station costs and operational expenditures for a wind plant.  The first two models are based on the NREL Cost and Scaling Model {\hyperref[theory:fingersh2006]{{[}1{]}}} and estimate balance of station costs (NREL\_CSM\_BOS) and operational expenditures (NREL\_CSM\_OPEX) for both land-based and offshore wind plants.  The latter software is a wrapper for an offshore operational expenditures model from the Energy Research Centre of the Netherlands (ECN) {\hyperref[theory:ecn2012]{{[}2{]}}} and one must have the model and license in order to use this model.  Only an OpenMDAO wrapper for the model is provided in this software set.

Plant\_CostsSE is implemented as an \href{http://openmdao.org/}{OpenMDAO} assembly.  All supporting code is also in OpenMDAO based on the Python programming language with the exception of the ECN Offshore OPEX model which is in Excel.  You must have the model and license in order to use this model.


\chapter{Installation}
\label{installation:installation}\label{installation::doc}
\begin{notice}{note}{prerequisites}
\begin{quote}

General: NumPy, SciPy, Swig, pyWin32, MatlPlotLib, Lxml, OpenMDAO

Wind Plant Framework: FUSED-Wind (Framework for Unified Systems Engineering and Design of Wind Plants)

Sub-Models: CommonSE

Supporting python packages: Pandas, Algopy, Zope.interface, Sphinx, Xlrd, PyOpt, py2exe, Pyzmq, Sphinxcontrib-bibtex, Sphinxcontrib-zopeext, Numpydoc, Ipython
\end{quote}
\end{notice}

Clone the repository at \href{https://github.com/WISDEM/Plant\_CostsSE}{https://github.com/WISDEM/Plant\_CostsSE}
or download the releases and uncompress/unpack (Plant\_CostsSE.py-0.1.0.tar.gz or Plant\_CostsSE.py-0.1.0.zip) from the website link at the bottom the {\color{red}\bfseries{}{}`Plant\_CostsSE site\textless{}http://nwtc.nrel.gov/Plant\_CostsSE\textgreater{}{}`\_}.

To install Plant\_CostsSE, first activate the OpenMDAO environment and then install with the following command.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{} }plugin install
\end{Verbatim}

To check if installation was successful try to import the module from within an activated OpenMDAO environment:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{} }python
\end{Verbatim}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{plant\PYGZus{}costsse.nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}bos.nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}bos}
\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{plant\PYGZus{}costsse.nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}opex.nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}opex}
\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{plant\PYGZus{}costsse.ecn\PYGZus{}opex\PYGZus{}offshore.ecn\PYGZus{}opex\PYGZus{}offshore}
\end{Verbatim}

Note that you must have the ECN Offshore OPEX model and license in order to use the latter module.  This software contains only the OpenMDAO wrapper for the model.

You may also run the unit tests which include functional and gradient tests.  Analytic gradients are provided for variables only so warnings will appear for missing gradients on model input parameters; these can be ignored.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{} }python src/test/test\PYGZus{}Plant\PYGZus{}CostsSE.py
\end{Verbatim}

An ``OK'' signifies that all the tests passed.

If you have the ECN model, you may run the ECN test which checks for a non-zero value for operational expenditures.  You will likely need to modify the code for the ECN model based on the version you have and its particular configuration.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{} }python src/test/test\PYGZus{}Plant\PYGZus{}CostsSE\PYGZus{}ECN.py
\end{Verbatim}

For software issues please use \href{https://github.com/WISDEM/Plant\_CostsSE/issues}{https://github.com/WISDEM/Plant\_CostsSE/issues}.  For functionality and theory related questions and comments please use the NWTC forum for \href{https://wind.nrel.gov/forum/wind/viewtopic.php?f=34\&t=1002}{Systems Engineering Software Questions}.

An HTML version of this documentation that contains further details and links to the source code is available at \href{http://wisdem.github.io/Plant\_CostsSE}{http://wisdem.github.io/Plant\_CostsSE}


\chapter{Tutorial}
\label{tutorial:tutorial-label}\label{tutorial::doc}\label{tutorial:tutorial}

\section{Tutorial for NREL\_CSM\_BOS}
\label{tutorial:tutorial-for-nrel-csm-bos}
As an example of NREL\_CSM\_BOS, let us simulate balance of station costs for a land-based wind plant.

The first step is to import the relevant files and set up the component.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} A simple test of nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}bos model}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{plant\PYGZus{}costsse.nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}bos.nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}bos} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{bos\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}assembly}

\PYG{n}{bos} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bos\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}assembly}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

The plant balance of station cost model relies on some turbine as well as plant input parameters that must be specified.  In this case, the wind turbine machine rating, rotor diameter, overall cost, and hub height need to be specified.  The rotor-nacelle-assembly (RNA) mass is also included but is not used in the model at this time.  For plant inputs, the number of turbines, sea depth, analysis year and month need to be specified.  A multiplier input is available if there is a desire to calibrate the model to some known wind plant costs.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Set input parameters}
\PYG{n}{bos} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bos\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}assembly}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{machine\PYGZus{}rating} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{5000.0}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{rotor\PYGZus{}diameter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{126.0}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}cost} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{5950209.28}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{hub\PYGZus{}height} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{90.0}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{RNA\PYGZus{}mass} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{256634.5} \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} RNA mass is not used in this simple model}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sea\PYGZus{}depth} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{20.0}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{year} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2009}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{month} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{12}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{multiplier} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}
\end{Verbatim}

We can now evaluate the plant balance of station costs.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

We then print out the resulting cost values.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Balance of Station Costs for an offshore wind plant with 100 NREL 5 MW turbines}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{BOS cost offshore: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}0:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{bos\PYGZus{}costs}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{BOS cost per turbine: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}0:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{bos\PYGZus{}costs} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print}
\end{Verbatim}

The result is:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Balance of Station Costs for an offshore wind plant with 100 NREL 5 MW turbines
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} BOS cost offshore: \PYGZdl{}766464743.61 USD
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} BOS cost per turbine: \PYGZdl{}7664647.44 USD
\end{Verbatim}

Next we repeat the process but change the input settings for an land-based wind plant.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sea\PYGZus{}depth} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.0}
\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}cost} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{5229222.77}

\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Balance of Station Costs for an land\PYGZhy{}based wind plant with 100 NREL 5 MW turbines}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{BOS cost land\PYGZhy{}based: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}0:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{bos\PYGZus{}costs}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{BOS cost per turbine: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}0:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{bos\PYGZus{}costs} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{bos}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print}
\end{Verbatim}

The new result is:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Balance of Station Costs for an land\PYGZhy{}based wind plant with 100 NREL 5 MW turbines
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} BOS cost onshore: \PYGZdl{}308453311.95 USD
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} BOS cost per turbine: \PYGZdl{}3084533.12 USD
\end{Verbatim}


\section{Tutorial for NREL\_CSM\_OPEX}
\label{tutorial:tutorial-for-nrel-csm-opex}
As an example of NREL\_CSM\_OPEX, let us simulate operational expenditures for a land-based wind plant.

The first step is to import the relevant files and set up the component.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} A simple test of nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}om model}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{plant\PYGZus{}costsse.nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}opex.nrel\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}opex} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}assembly}

\PYG{n}{om} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}csm\PYGZus{}assembly}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

The plant operational expenditures model relies on some turbine as well as plant input parameters that must be specified.  For the OPEX model, the turbine machine rating must be specified as well as plant parameters including the net annual energy production of the plant, the number of turbines and the sea depth.  The analysis year and month must also be specified.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Ste input parameters}
\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{machine\PYGZus{}rating} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{5000.0} \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Need to manipulate input or underlying component will not execute}
\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{net\PYGZus{}aep} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1701626526.28}
\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sea\PYGZus{}depth} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{20.0}
\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{year} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2009}
\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{month} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{12}
\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}
\end{Verbatim}

We can now evaluate the plant operational expenditures.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

We then print out the resulting cost values.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Average annual operational expenditures for an offshore wind plant with 100 NREL 5 MW turbines}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{OPEX offshore \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}:.2f\PYGZcb{}: USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{avg\PYGZus{}annual\PYGZus{}opex}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Preventative OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}breakdown}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{preventative\PYGZus{}opex} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Corrective OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}breakdown}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{corrective\PYGZus{}opex} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Land Lease OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}breakdown}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{lease\PYGZus{}opex} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print}
\end{Verbatim}

The result is:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Average annual operational expenditures for an offshore wind plant with 100 NREL 5 MW turbines
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} OPEX offshore: \PYGZdl{}47575391.88 USD
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Preventative OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}364542.00 USD
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Corrective OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}91048.39 USD
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Land Lease OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}20163.53 USD
\end{Verbatim}

Next we repeat the process but change the input settings for an land-based wind plant.

\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Preventative OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}breakdown}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{preventative\PYGZus{}opex} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{om}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number}\PYG{p}{)}

\section{Tutorial for ECN\_Offshore\_OPEX}
\label{tutorial:tutorial-for-ecn-offshore-opex}
As an example of ECN\_Offshore\_OPEX, let us simulate operational expenditures for an offshore wind plant.

The first step is to import the relevant files and set up the component.  Note that the location of the ECN model must be specified as an input to the wrapper.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} A simple test of ecn\PYGZus{}offshore\PYGZus{}om model}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{plant\PYGZus{}costsse.ecn\PYGZus{}offshore\PYGZus{}opex.ecn\PYGZus{}offshore\PYGZus{}opex} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}ecn\PYGZus{}assembly}

\PYG{n}{om2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}ecn\PYGZus{}assembly}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{C:/Models/ECN Model/ECN O\PYGZam{}M Model.xls}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Substitute your own path to the ECN Model}
\end{Verbatim}

The plant operational expenditures model relies on some turbine as well as plant input parameters that must be specified.  At the moment these include the turbine machine rating and overall cost as well as the number of turbines in the plant and the expected project lifetime.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Set input parameters}
\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{machine\PYGZus{}rating} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{5000.0}
\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}cost} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mf}{9000000.0}
\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}
\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{project\PYGZus{}lifetime} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{20}
\end{Verbatim}

We can now evaluate the plant operational expenditures.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

We then print out the resulting cost values.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Average annual operational expenditures for an offshore wind plant with 100 NREL 5 MW turbines}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{OPEX offshore: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{avg\PYGZus{}annual\PYGZus{}opex}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Preventative OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}breakdown}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{preventative\PYGZus{}opex} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Corrective OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}breakdown}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{corrective\PYGZus{}opex} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Land Lease OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}\PYGZob{}:.2f\PYGZcb{} USD}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}breakdown}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{lease\PYGZus{}opex} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turbine\PYGZus{}number}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{and plant availability of \PYGZob{}:.1f\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZpc{}}\PYG{l+s}{ }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{format}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{availability}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mf}{100.0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print}
\end{Verbatim}

The results will vary depending on the configuration of the model but example results are provided here:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Average annual operational expenditures for an offshore wind plant with 100 NREL 5 MW turbines
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} OPEX offshore: \PYGZdl{}60080182.54 USD
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Preventative OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}56525.74 USD
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Corrective OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}389276.09 USD
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} Land Lease OPEX by turbine: \PYGZdl{}105000.00 USD
\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} and plant availability of 94.3\PYGZpc{}
\end{Verbatim}

    \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} variables}
    \PYG{n}{machine\PYGZus{}rating} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{units} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{kW}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{iotype} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{in}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{desc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{rated power for a wind turbine}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{net\PYGZus{}aep} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{units} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{kW * h}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{iotype} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{in}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{desc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{annual energy production for the plant}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} parameters}
    \PYG{n}{sea\PYGZus{}depth} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{20.0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{units} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{m}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{iotype} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{in}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{desc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{sea depth for offshore wind plant}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{year} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2009}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{units}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{yr}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{iotype}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{in}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{desc}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{year for project start}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n}{opex\PYGZus{}breakdown} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{VarTree}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{OPEXVarTree}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{iotype}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{out}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\chapter{Theory}
\label{theory::doc}\label{theory:theory}\label{theory:id1}
The theory for the NREL models in this software are based directly on the work described in the reference for the NREL Cost and Scaling Model {\hyperref[theory:fingersh2006]{{[}1{]}}}.  The NREL Cost and Scaling Model provides a simple cost and sizing tool to estimate wind plant cost of energy based on a small number of input parameters such as rotor diameter, hub height and rated power.  The models here extract the balance of station and operational expenditure calculators from the model as stand-alone modules.

The theory for the ECN Offshore OPEX Model can be found in {\hyperref[theory:ecn2012]{{[}2{]}}}, {\hyperref[theory:obdam2011a]{{[}3{]}}} and {\hyperref[theory:obdam2011b]{{[}4{]}}}.  This model is an external model and only an OpenMDAO wrapper for the model is provided here.



\begin{thebibliography}{1}
\bibitem[1]{1}{\phantomsection\label{theory:fingersh2006} 
L. Fingersh, M. Hand, and A. Laxson. Wind turbine design cost and scaling model. NREL/TP-500-40566, National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, December 2005.
}
\bibitem[2]{2}{\phantomsection\label{theory:ecn2012} 
ECN. Ecn wind industrial support. Technical Report, Energy Research Centre of the Netherlands, January 2023. \href{http://www.ewis.nl/fileadmin/ecn/units/wind/docs/EWIS/SP-310\_OM\_Tool\_Brochure.pdf}{URL: http://www.ewis.nl/fileadmin/ecn/units/wind/docs/EWIS/SP-310\_OM\_Tool\_Brochure.pdf}.
}
\bibitem[3]{3}{\phantomsection\label{theory:obdam2011a} 
T.S. Obdam, H., Braam, and L. Rademakers. User guide and model description of ecn o\&m toolversion 4. Technical Report, Energy Research Centre of the Netherlands, 2011.
}
\bibitem[4]{4}{\phantomsection\label{theory:obdam2011b} 
T.S. Obdam and T. van der Zee. Ecn o\&m tool case study for a far offshore wind farm. Technical Report, Energy Research Centre of the Netherlands, 2011.
}
\end{thebibliography}
